titleproper.value: Guide to the Mark Straus Papers and Photographs <num>ALBA.277</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2017-07-18T20:00:00</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: Mark Straus (1909-1993) was a Jewish doctor and who served with the Abraham Lincoln Brigade in the Spanish Civil War.  After graduating from the University of Alabama he moved to Paris and received his medical degree from the University of Paris in 1936.  A radical leftist, Straus went to Spain as part of the American Medical Bureau, Group IV, which arrived there in May 1937.  Initially in charge of the Washington Battalion's medical unit, he went on to become chief medical officer for the 15th International Brigade.  At the request of the Medical Bureau he returned to the U.S. on the S.S. Aquitania on July 12, 1938.  The collection consists chiefly of correspondence and photographs documenting Mark Straus's life before and during the Spanish Civil War.  Some additional material relating to his brother and fellow physician Bernard Straus is also included.

p.value: Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Tamiment Library & Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives for more information and to schedule an appointment, tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu or 212-998-2630.

Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

After the war, Straus succeeded Dr. Edward Barsky as chairman of the Joint Anti-Fascist Refugee Committee, when Barsky was sent to prison for refusing to cooperate with the House Committee on Un-American Activities in 1950.  Straus taught at New York Medical College and at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals and later had a private practice in Brooklyn, NY.  He held another medical position as a consultant to the Fur Dressers and Dyers Joint Board, conducting research on the occupational hazards of dyes.

<emph render="bold">Series III: Photographs, 1927-1938</emph> consists mostly of photographs of Mark Straus and others before and during the Spanish Civil War.  A set of dental x-rays of his brother, Bernard Straus is also included.

corpname.value: Spain. Ejercito Popular de la Republica. Abraham Lincoln Battalion
